channel.title: Handlers
channel.description:
i was writing up the herblore in my client.java and this came up..
client.java:16042: code too large public void parseIncomingPackets(){ ^ Note: stream:java uses or overrides a deprecated API. Note: Recompile with -Xlint:deprecation for details. 1 error Compiling Finished. Press any key to continue . . .
I'm assuming this means that there's too much junk in my client.java class, and am trying to get some guidance as to writing handlers in separate text files for skill classes. that way they don't have to take up so much space in my client.java haha.. any help would be much appreciated, my msn -- drs023@hotmail.com, or log onto my private server with any client (most basic ones are compatible) -- warrscape.no-ip.org

item.title: Handlers
item.dc:creator: @R3minice R3minice
item.description:
@R3minice wrote:

[quote=“deathschaos9, post:1, topic:341719”][size=15pt]Code Too Large[/size]

This error is popping up more and more, and many people dont know why this happens. In a Jave method, its size cannot exceed 64KB. Why? Google it. What to do when this occurs? Well, you can split the one method into two parts. Say you have a method called parseIncomingPackets() (this is a RSPS reference) and it exceeded 64KB. A simple way to rid of this error would be to split it into two parts by creating a nother method such as parseIncomingPackets2(). Here is an example,

public void parseIncomingPackets() { // 64KB, compiler gives an error }Split up,

[code=java]public void parseIncomingPackets() {
// below 64KB, no error
}

public void parseIncomingPackets2() {
// below 64KB, no error
}
[/code]Also, be noted you have to call the second method at one point probably like,

public void parseIncomingPackets() { // your code here parseIncomingPackets2(); }[/quote]

Read full topic

item.title: Handlers
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

Could a bracket be ending to far below? Causing it to take everything below it to be in the method to?
